Dear Ms. McClain:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For any repeat violations, include an assessment of why the previous
corrective action plan was ineffective.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.

ALLEGATION 1:
Youth A has a history of abuse while in her biological mother’s care. Staff allowed
Youth A’s biological mother to have contact with her. Since then, Youth A has been
self-harming.
INVESTIGATION:
A complaint was received on 10/6/20 which stated that Youth A, who is diagnosed
with depression and a cognitive impairment, suffered abuse while in the care of her
biological mother. Sometime within the past few weeks the staff at the facility
allowed Youth A to have contact with her biological mother. Since this contact Youth
A has been self-harming. The complaint indicated that staff did not check bio-mom’s
identification prior to Youth A seeing her.
Foster Care worker (FCW) Interview: The FCW was contacted on 10/8/20 via
telephone. She stated Youth A saw her mom while at the facility. She was notified by
e-mail from the facility. The FCW said there is a no-contact order in place between
Youth A and her mother and she is to only have supervised phone calls. When she
found out about the visit, she went to see Youth A. She found out that Youth A had
been calling her mom to discuss her mom visiting for Youth A's birthday. The FCW
said Youth A's calls with mom were not being supervised. Youth A’s mom came to
the facility with other family members. Youth A saw her mom through the window.
Youth A went to Staff 2 and asked her if she could see her mom. Staff 2 and Youth
A were close. Staff 2 allowed Youth A to see her mom. Youth A saw her mom briefly
and staff were present. The FCW said that staff did not check the mom's ID or the
contact sheet prior to allowing the visit. She said the staff may not have known this
was Youth A's bio-mom because she also has an adoptive mother she visits with.
The FCW said this visit was very triggering for Youth A and she cut herself this past
weekend. She who is she? Youth A or FCW? did not tell anyone tell them what?
about the visit or the cutting? until days later.
Youth A Interview: Youth A was interviewed at the facility on 10/14/20. She stated
she has been at the facility for about nine or ten months. She said she is ready to
leave but is waiting for approval for her to go to adult foster care. Youth A stated
they can have visitors if they are listed on their contact list. She said she can have
her adoptive mom, worker, foster mom, and foster dad all visit her at the facility. She
stated she is not allowed to see her bio-family. She stated that was decided by the
judge. She said she can talk to her bio-mom, bio-aunt, and bio sister on the phone
but someone from the facility has to listen in. Youth A stated she talked to them
about coming to the facility to see her. She said she did not know who listened in on
the call, but she did remember who was working when they came to see her. She
said Staff 1, Staff 2, and another staff were working. She said her bio-family visited
her the same day she had the phone call. She said the same people were working
3

when she made the call and when her family showed up at the facility. Her bio-mom
called the office to drop off Youth A's birthday stuff. Youth A saw her mom's car.
Youth A told the staff if she did not see her family then she would have a bad
birthday. She said Staff 1 looked in the contact book, gave her a mask, and had
Staff 2 take her out to see her family. Youth A stated that Staff 2 asked Staff 1 if he
wanted her to take Youth A out to see her family and Staff 1 said yes. Youth A
stated she did not want to get anyone in trouble or fired. She stated Staff 2 took her
out to see her family and did not ask for them to show their ID's. Youth A said she
hugged her family and they took pictures. Youth A said she is not doing well, and
she wants to see her bio-family. She said she has people at the facility she can talk
to when she is upset
Chief Administrator (CA) Interview: The CA met with this consultant at the facility
on 10/14/20. She was informed of the allegations. The CA stated that they have a
form filled out by the workers when the youth are admitted. This form indicates who
the youth is allowed to have contact with and what type of contact. She supplied a
Client Contact List for Youth A. Youth A's contact list was handwritten and stated
that Youth A could have supervised phone calls with bio-mom, bio-aunt, and bio
sister. For visits it indicated no visits and in the margin stated that the court ordered
no visits occur with bio-mom. For her bio-aunt and sister the form indicated no visits.
The CA stated Staff 2 no longer works at the facility.
Staff 1 Interview: Staff 1 was interviewed at the facility on 10/14/20. He stated that
it was Youth A's birthday and she had a visit with her adoptive mother. She came
back from that visit and bio-mom called to say she was at the facility. He stated it
was staff oversight that Youth A was allowed to see her mom. He said the bio-mom
just came to drop something off to Youth A. He said there was a corrective action
put in place and staff were told there was a court order for no contact between Youth
A and her bio-mom. Staff 1 said he knew it was bio-mom that was at the facility and
that Youth A went to see her. He thought Youth A was allowed to see bio-mom. He
stated bio-mom had not visited before. He stated that Youth A arrived at the facility
during COVID and visits had stopped. When she met with her bio-mom he had been
out of practice with visits. He stated Staff 2 took Youth A to see bio-mom. He stated
that allowed contacts are listed in a book, they also get an e-mail regarding contacts,
and it is in the sign-in book. He stated they are supposed to check the phone log
when a visitor comes. He stated he did not think the phone log was checked prior to
the visit. He stated it should be checked for every visit.
Staff 2 Interview: Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 12/1/20. She stated she
no longer works at the facility. She stated that Youth A’s mother came to the facility
to drop off birthday presents. Staff 2 said that she and her co-worker discussed
Youth A seeing her mom and they agreed it was not an issue. She stated that there
was a no-contact order in place for Youth A and her mom, but she did not have
access to that order. She stated the staff are supposed to check the contact list
before a visit, but this was technically not a visit. She stated she checked with Staff 1
who told her it was fine. Staff 2 stated this was all new to her as she had only been
4

working at the facility for a few months. Staff 2 was asked if Youth A talked to her
mom on the phone. She stated Youth A did talk to her mom on the phone that day
but that her phone calls were not supervised with mom.
Staff Files: Staff 1 was hired on 1/2/19. He had one growth plan in 1/2/19 to ensure
he became more familiar with his job responsibilities, client treatment plans, attend
team meetings, and be a good role model. Staff 2 was hired on 7/17/20 and her last
day working for the facility was 10/17/20. She did not have any disciplines. Both staff
received training on family contacts during their orientation and attended a meeting
on 7/28/20 in which expectations for youth contacts were discussed.
Policy: The facility’s policy on visits does not outline a procedure for checking the
contact sheet and visitors ID prior to allowing a visit.
ALLEGATION 2:
Youth B was allowed an unsupervised visit with her mother even though visits are
supposed to be supervised by staff.
INVESTIGATION:
While at the facility conducting the above investigation The CA reported that Youth
B, who goes by they, them, or their was allowed to visit with their mother alone. The
CA stated that mom brought Youth B to the facility to be admitted so the Supervisor,
who did the intake, thought it was ok for them to visit alone.
The CA supplied a Client Contact List for Youth A and Youth B. Youth B's Client
Contact List is typed and yes or no is highlighted for visits or phone calls. For Youth
B's mother the sheet has yes highlighted to indicate she can have phone calls and
on-ground visit with mom. Under monitored, yes is highlighted, indicating that phone
calls and visits must be monitored.
Supervisor Interview: The Supervisor was interviewed at the facility on 10/14/20.
He stated that Youth B's mother came for a scheduled visit. She called and he
walked down with Youth B to check mom in. He said he did not check Youth B's
book because mom had brought Youth A into the facility at intake. He stated it was
listed in Youth B's book on the contact sheet that she was to only have supervised
visits with mom. He stated that the case manager received the information from the
FCW, then she put the information on the contact list form. The Supervisor stated
that when signing people in for visits the contact sheet is in front of the sign in sheet,
so it would need to be flipped over in order to see it. He stated that Youth B's visit
went well. They sat outside at the gazebo then they called to get into a visit room to
visit more.
5

Youth B Interview: Youth B was interviewed at the facility on 10/14/20. They stated
they have been at the facility for two weeks. They visit with mom on Sundays from
3:00 to 5:00. They said their visits are supervised on-grounds but the first visit they
had was not supervised because DHHS made a mistake.
Supervisor Employee File: The Supervisor was hired on 6/20/11. He had 4
disciplines and 1 growth plan. The disciplines were for AWOL risks, goals of the
program, reporting concerns to the therapist, and dealing with client behaviors. The
last discipline occurred on 1/17/20. The growth plan was to help improve supervisor
role, balancing staff’s schedule, reviewing activities, facilitating team meetings, and
timeliness of reporting. A team meeting occurred on 7/28/20 in which expectations
for the youth’s contacts was presented
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4122 Resident and parent visitation.
An institution shall provide for visits between each resident
and the resident's parents, unless parental rights have been
terminated or the resident's record contains documentation
that visitation is detrimental to the resident.
ANALYSIS: Youth A’s contact form clearly states visits are not allowed with
her bio-family; however, Youth A, Staff 1, and Staff 2 all
indicated Youth A was allowed to see her bio-family.
The contact sheet for Youth B states they are not to have
unsupervised visits with mom; however, the supervisor and
Youth B both state they had an unsupervised visit with mom.
Technical assistance: It is recommended the facility put
procedures for visits and phone calls in writing and include it as
part of the staff training.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6

Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan it is recommended that this
